name: Fairy Falls Trail
why_locals_love_it: Incredible views of Grand Prismatic Spring from the overlook and ends with a picturesque waterfall.
water_reminder: Carry at least 1 liter per person. Summer heat can sneak up on you.

name: Purple Mountain Trail
why_locals_love_it: Unbeatable views over the Madison River valley—less crowded than other lookout hikes.
bear_safety: Yes, carry bear spray. Known grizzly activity in the area.
water_reminder: Bring 2 liters minimum. No water on trail.

name: Riverside Trail
why_locals_love_it: Peaceful riverside stroll just outside town. Great for elk or fox sightings in the morning.
bear_safety: Low risk but always recommended to carry bear spray.
water_reminder: Bring water. Shaded but no access points.

name: Harlequin Lake Trail
why_locals_love_it: Quick and lovely trail to a peaceful lake—perfect for stretching your legs.
water_reminder: Short trail but bring a small bottle, especially in summer.

name: Two Ribbons Trail
why_locals_love_it: Boardwalk makes it easy for families or those with mobility concerns to explore the riverside habitat.
bear_safety: Low risk, but spray is still recommended.

name: Lava Creek Trail (Upper Section)
why_locals_love_it: Lesser-known trail with great trout-watching spots and a peaceful creek setting.
bear_safety: Yes, carry bear spray. Moose and bear reported seasonally.
water_reminder: Creek nearby, but still carry your own water.

name: Gneiss Creek Trail
why_locals_love_it: Backcountry hike that’s great for solitude and cutthroat trout access.
bear_safety: Absolutely. Bear spray and proper food storage required.
water_reminder: Bring water and a filter. Remote area.

name: Yellowstone River Picnic Area Trail
why_locals_love_it: River canyon views with a great chance of spotting bighorn sheep.
water_reminder: Bring 1–2 liters. No access en route.

name: Firehole Lake Drive Boardwalk Hikes
why_locals_love_it: Scenic drive with short strolls to hot springs and geysers.
water_reminder: Carry water, especially in the heat.
